introduction.p: Suppose that you are driving a car on the highway using cruise control so that you drive at a constant speed. The time, T (measured in hours), it takes to drive 50 miles depends on the constant rate, s (measured in miles per hour) at which you are driving. Since
and thus we know that T(s) = \frac{50}{s}\text{.}

For instance, observe that T(75) = \frac{50}{75} = \frac{2}{3}\text{,} so it takes \frac{2}{3} of an hour to drive 50 miles at 75 miles per hour, and the point (75, \frac{2}{3}) lies on the graph of T(s)\text{.}

statement.p: Give three points which lie on the graph of T\text{,} separated by commas.
Which of the following statements and explanations is true about the graph of T(s)\text{?}

li.p: The function is concave up because as speed goes up, travel time goes up.
The function is concave down because as speed goes up, travel time goes down.
The function is increasing because as speed goes up, travel time goes up.
The function is decreasing because as speed goes up, travel time goes down.

statement.p: What is the value of T(60)\text{?} Include units on your answer.
Which of the following is the best explanation of the meaning of this value in context?

li.p: T(60) is the time it takes to travel 50 miles at a speed of 60 mph.
T(60) is how fast the travel time is changing when the car is traveling at a speed of 60 mph.

statement.p: Recall the average rate of change of a function f(x) on an interval [a,b] is
Determine the average rate of T on the interval [60,65]\text{,} AV_{[60, 65]}\text{.} Include units on your answer.

The sign of AV_{[60, 65]} is
positive
negative
This sign makes sense because

li.p: T is increasing from 60 to 65 mph.
T is decreasing from 60 to 65 mph.
T is concave up from 60 to 65 mph.
T is concave down from 60 to 65 mph.

statement.p: Which of the following explains the meaning of the value of AV_{[60, 65]}\text{?}

li.p: AV_{[60, 65]} is the amount of hours T has changed from 60 to 65 mph.
AV_{[60, 65]} is the change in speed from 60 to 65 mph.
AV_{[60, 65]} is the average change in hours the trip takes when the speed changes from 60 to 65 mph.

introduction.p: Let f(x)=\cos(x) and let T_2(x)=b_0+b_1x+b_2x^2\text{.} We find the values of b_0, b_1 and b_2 that make the functions \cos(x) and T_2(x) have the same height, slope, and concavity at x=0\text{.}

statement.p: Complete the table below by computing derivatives of T_2(x) and \cos(x) and evaluating them at x=0 as directed.
Now, since we want T_2(x) and \cos(x) to have the same height at x=0\text{,} set T_2(0)=f(0)\text{.}
This implies b_0={}.
Since we want T_2(x) and \cos(x) to have the same slope at x=0\text{,} set T_2'(0)=f'(0)\text{.}
This implies b_1={}.
Finally, since we want T_2(x) and \cos(x) to have the same concavity at x=0\text{,} set T_2''(0)=f''(0)\text{.}
This implies b_2={}.
Putting everything together, what is the resulting formula for T_2(x)=b_0+b_1x+b_2x^2\text{?}

introduction.p: Let f(x)=\ln(1+x) and let T_2(x)=b_0+b_1x+b_2x^2\text{.} We find the values of b_0, b_1 and b_2 that make the functions \ln(1+x) and T_2(x) have the same height, slope, and concavity at x=0\text{.}

statement.p: Complete the table below by computing derivatives of T_2(x) and \ln(1+x) and evaluating them at x=0 as directed.
Now, since we want T_2(x) and \ln(1+x) to have the same height at x=0\text{,} set T_2(0)=f(0)\text{.}
This implies b_0={}.
Since we want T_2(x) and \ln(1+x) to have the same slope at x=0\text{,} set T_2'(0)=f'(0)\text{.}
This implies b_1={}.
Finally, since we want T_2(x) and \ln(1+x) to have the same concavity at x=0\text{,} set T_2''(0)=f''(0)\text{.}
This implies b_2={}.
Putting everything together, what is the resulting formula for T_2(x)=b_0+b_1x+b_2x^2\text{?}

introduction.p: Let f(x)=\sin(x) and let T_3(x)=c_0+c_1x+c_2x^2+c_3x^3\text{.} We find the values of c_0,\ldots,c_3 that make the functions \sin(x) and T_3(x) have the same height, slope, concavity, and third derivative value at x=0\text{.}

statement.p: Complete the table below by computing derivatives of T_3(x) and \sin(x) and evaluating them at x=0 as directed.
Now, since we want T_3(x) and \sin(x) to have the same height at x=0\text{,} set T_3(0)=f(0)\text{.}
This implies c_0={}.
Since we want T_3(x) and \sin(x) to have the same slope at x=0\text{,} set T_3'(0)=f'(0)\text{.}
This implies c_1={}.
Since we want T_3(x) and \sin(x) to have the same concavity at x=0\text{,} set T_3''(0)=f''(0)\text{.}
This implies c_2={}.
Finally, since we want T_3(x) and \sin(x) to have the same third derivative value at x=0\text{,} set T_3'''(0)=f'''(0)\text{.}
This implies c_3={}.
Putting everything together, what is the resulting formula for T_3(x)=c_0+c_1x+c_2x^2+c_3x^3\text{?}
Suppose that T_2(x)=c_0+c_1x+c_2x^2 is the second degree Taylor polynomial for the function f about x=0. What can you say about the signs of c_0, c_1, c_2 if f has the graph given below?

p.em: (For each, enter + if the term is positive, and - if it is negative. Note that because this is essentially multiple choice problem it will not show which parts of your answer are correct or incorrect.)

statement.p: c_0 is
c_1 is
c_2 is

static.solution:
T_2(x) is the second degree Taylor polynomial for f(x) about x=0, T_2(0)=f(0), which says c_0=f(0). Since \frac{d}{dx}T_2(x) \big|_{x=0} = f'(0), c_1=f'(0); and since \frac{d^2}{dx^2} T_2(x) \big|_{x=0} = f''(0), 2c_2=f''(0). In other words, c_0 is the y-intercept of f(x), c_1 is the slope of the tangent line to f(x) at x=0 and c_2 tells us the concavity of f(x) near x=0.
Thus c_0 \lt 0; c_1 > 0; and c_2 > 0

introduction.p: Let f(x)=\sin(x) and let T_3(x)=c_0+c_1x+c_2x^2+c_3x^3\text{.} Our goal is to find the values of c_0,\ldots,c_3 that make the sine function and its derivative values agree with those of the cubic polynomial T_3 at a=0 and to study the resulting degree 3 approximation of the sine function.

statement.p: As in previous work, the derivatives of T_3(x) and their respective values at a=0 are those shown in the following table. Compute the various derivatives of f(x)=\sin(x) and evaluate them at a=0 accordingly, recording your results in the left side of the table.
Putting it all together, what is the resulting formula for T_3(x)\text{?}
Recall that the tangent line approximation T_1 to f(x)=\sin(x) at a=0 is T_1(x)=x\text{,} as plotted below. On the same axes, weve plotted the cubic approximation T_3 you found in part (b).
What do you observe about the approximation T_3 generates compared to the tangent line approximation T_1\text{?}

li.p: The cubic approximation is closer to the function for more values of x.
The tangent line approximation is closer to the function for more values of x.
Both approximate the function equally well.

statement.p: What do you notice about the size and sign of those differences?

In our work so far, weve seen that raising the degree of polynomial improves the approximation of the original function f(x)\text{.} If we decided we wanted to find a degree 9 approximation to f(x) = \sin(x)\text{,} wed need to find a polynomial whose value and first 9 derivatives match those of the sine function at a = 0\text{.}
Fill in the blanks below to determine the next six derivatives of f(x) = \sin(x)\text{,} up to f^{(9)}(x)\text{.}
What pattern do you notice in the derivatives of f(x)=\sin(x)\text{?}

introduction.p: A function f defined on -4 \lt x \lt 4 is given by the graph below. Note: to the right of x = 2, the graph of f is exhibiting infinite oscillatory behavior similar to the function \sin(\pi/x). Assume that f(2)=-2.5.

statement.p: Determine each of the following limits. If a limit does not exist, enter DNE.
Determine each of the following function values, then indicate whether the limit equals the function value at that point. If a value does not exist, enter DNE.

Does f(-3) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow -3} f(x)}?
?
yes
no

Does f(-2) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow -2} f(x)}?
?
yes
no

Does f(-1) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow -1} f(x)}?
?
yes
no

Does f(0) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} f(x)}?
?
yes
no

Does f(1) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 1} f(x)}?
?
yes
no

Does f(2) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 2} f(x)}?
?
yes
no

Does f(3) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 3} f(x)}?
?
yes
no

Estimate the each value of f'(a), if the derivative exists at x=a. In particular, based on the graph, ask yourself if it is reasonable to say that the graph of f has a tangent line at (a, f(a)) for each of the given a-values. If so, visually estimate the slope of the tangent line to find the value of f'(a). If the derivative does not exist, enter DNE.

introduction.p: A function f defined on -4 \lt x \lt 4 is given by the graph below. Note: to the right of x = 2, the graph of f is exhibiting infinite oscillatory behavior similar to the function \sin(\pi/x). Assume that f(2)=-2.5.

statement.p: Determine each of the following limits. If a limit does not exist, enter DNE.
Determine each of the following function values, then indicate whether the limit equals the function value at that point. If a value does not exist, enter DNE.

Does f(-3) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow -3} f(x)}?
?
Yes.
No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.
No, the value is undefined.
No, the limit does not exist.
No, both the value and the limit don't exist.

Does f(-2) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow -2} f(x)}?
?
Yes.
No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.
No, the value is undefined.
No, the limit does not exist.
No, both the value and the limit don't exist.

Does f(-1) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow -1} f(x)}?
?
Yes.
No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.
No, the value is undefined.
No, the limit does not exist.
No, both the value and the limit don't exist.

Does f(0) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} f(x)}?
?
Yes.
No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.
No, the value is undefined.
No, the limit does not exist.
No, both the value and the limit don't exist.

Does f(1) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 1} f(x)}?
?
Yes.
No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.
No, the value is undefined.
No, the limit does not exist.
No, both the value and the limit don't exist.

Does f(2) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 2} f(x)}?
?
Yes.
No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.
No, the value is undefined.
No, the limit does not exist.
No, both the value and the limit don't exist.

Does f(3) = \displaystyle{\lim_{x\rightarrow 3} f(x)}?
?
Yes.
No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.
No, the value is undefined.
No, the limit does not exist.
No, both the value and the limit don't exist.

p.m: {\verb!No, both the value and limit exist but aren't equal.!}

statement.p: Estimate the each value of f'(a), if the derivative exists at x=a. In particular, based on the graph, ask yourself if it is reasonable to say that the graph of f has a tangent line at (a, f(a)) for each of the given a-values. If so, visually estimate the slope of the tangent line to find the value of f'(a). If the derivative does not exist, enter DNE.
